text:
CCOs and CROs that I talk to describe
similar challenges with adapting

their risk management
and compliance for the cloud.

The users of cloud services
within your organization

want to move fast and start
using new services and features
as soon they are released.

And that is normal because
these services and features

could accelerate development
by weeks and sometimes
months.

However, risk management
and compliance teams require

time to understand these new
features and services.

They need to ensure the right
controls are in place to meet

risk mitigation and compliance
requirements at the same pace
as the users of cloud services.

So, Iâ€™ve often asked the GRC
teams to consider using the cloud

to manage risk and compliance. So
how do we do that?

With AWS, your technical
teams can innovate faster
with less time between changes.

This can be achieved through
a standardized approach

and abstraction of the underlying
infrastructure.

By introducing technical
controls into the standardized

approach, you enforce corporate
policy and rules for technology.

Because of this, you can build
risk management and compliance

controls into the early lifecycle
of your transformation

projects. Secondly,
when building your controls

on AWS, you can take advantage
of over 300 AWS security
features and services.

Taking advantage of these features
and services rather than developing

your controls from scratch
can save your teams time and
effort.

Some customers try to build
all the controls they will ever
need at the beginning.

They usually find that this
approach tends to slow down

cloud adoption. Other
customers who preferred

an iterative approach had better
results.

The iterative approach allows
your GRC teams to get familiar

with risk management and compliance
in the cloud.

This in turn leads to more efficiency
and greater confidence
in the controls they select.

As you shift towards deploying
controls through standardized

approaches and leverage
AWS provided controls,

iterations can occur faster,
leading to continuous

improvement of your control
environment.

With these two approaches,
you can keep pace with your

organizations demand for cloud
services, adjust to changing

regulatory environment,
and guide cloud adoption
confidently.
